column1: The kidneys play a crucial role in regulating acid-base homeostasis in the body
They achieve this by excreting hydrogen ions, which are responsible for acidity
Simultaneously, the kidneys reabsorb bicarbonate, a base, back into the bloodstream
This dual process helps to maintain the proper pH balance
Excreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate are separate mechanisms that work together
The excretion of hydrogen ions is essential to rid the body of excess acid
Reabsorbing bicarbonate increases the bicarbonate concentration in the blood, which acts as a buffer against acids
If the kidneys fail to perform these functions adequately, acid-base imbalances can occur
The precise regulation of hydrogen ions and bicarbonate is vital for maintaining life
In summary, the kidneys manage acid-base homeostasis by excreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate, ensuring the body's pH remains stable
